Great place to walk around. We spent an afternoon walking around Palermo and they have a new shopping area near the train station that is a great stop for an ice cream on a hot day and some shopping also. Continue thru Palermo Soho where you can find cool stores and restaurants.

place to be. you can be in palermo and have everything without living this place... its different palermos so everybody can find sth they like. a lot of small shops, restaurants, music, bars.. very buenos aires...
Soho of BA. Palermo is a charming neighborhood in BA, with many shops, parks, restaurants, boutique hotels and trees. It makes for great walking and shopping, as well as people watching.

Picturesque and lively neighbourhood. Beautiful neighbourhood, with nice, low-rise buildings and cobbled tree-lined streets, huge nightlife with numerous nice bars and restaurants with courtyard, terraces or tables on the pavements, young crowd, design and fashion shops. Staying there as a visitor may not be the optimal solution though, as you need to get the metro to the main attractions of the city and with taxis being quite cheap it is very easy to visit Palermo at night.
Quality area. Palermo is a great area where I felt safe and welcomed. It offered a lot of restaurant options and taxi cabs were always accessible.
very nice atmosphere. it was fabulous the Bife de Chorizo we had was outstanding and the wine was perfect and the Quilnes beer very good alsol

New year in Palermo is a great option!. We had dinner at Meridiano 58, which served a great menu. There was a show in the street, just in front of the restaurant, and people danced to a band playing Brazilian music.

Quiet neighborhood. It is long walk from Puerto Madero but like always we walk,there are means of other transportation, subway, taxis, buses, but we walk. It is worth ed. Meet people, see so many places, but most of all the moment you turn left from Avenida Santa Fe to Armenia things change. All of a sudden from busy streets od Buenos Aires you find yourself in quiet neighborhood filled with older but very preserved buildings, cafes, friendly people. There we had nice time in small Palermo Viejo park, but rewarding, fed some doves.

Great to for everything. We (my girlfriend and I) spent a month in the area. It got a lot of nice street cafes and everything from haute-cuisine to cheap but good food. Palermo also is the epicenter to go out, which is a bit pricey though. You can do lots of shopping there but this is expensive in that area.

Cafes & restaurants & boutiques abound. We stayed in an apartment in Palermo and were very happy with this barrio. The streets are alive with cafes, restaurants, boutiques and dancing, and many ice cream parlors. The only side note is that there is street noise into the wee hours of the morning every night - but that's part of the life.

Chic Palermo. Palermo is hip, colourful and trendy indeed. The barrio is all that one reads in the travel books and online. Initially thought to stay in Palermo but we are glad that we did not as it is busy. A fun place to shop, eat and people watch but to be frank, Palermo may be slightly over rated, especially if one is to compare it to the soho areas of New York and London. That may not be fair, but the comparisons have been made. Still worth a walk through. We visited twice and on one of the nights, a summer deluge began and the streets became flooded with both water and garbage. Watching people jump, walk barefeet (to save their shoes) through the water was the evenings entertainment as we ate.
Nice neighborhood. You got all you need (restaurants, bar, recreation areas, shops) within walking distance.Enjoy Argentinas finest dining/drinking

Wonderful Neighbourhood to Shop/Dine. This was a great area to just walk around for hours exploring different shops and restaurants. We felt totally safe. We visited this area 3 times and still did not see all it had to offer

Really nice neighborhood. The Palermo neighborhood is where we stayed and just by looking around the city from a tour bus, I'm really happy we did. There are a lot of horror stories about South America, but most of the ones we'd heard were because people chose to stay in pretty scary sections of the city.

The Best Neighborhood. We love this neighborhood with its wealth of cafes and restaurants. Can find fresh croissants or empanadas, salads or quiches, sushi or parrillas. The little grocery stores make it easy to pick up snacks and wine. Can get to other areas of the city by bus, metro, or taxi.

Watch were you put your feet!. Palermo is billed as a bohemian community and it lives up to its reputation with a mish mash of buildings, shops, restaurants and small hotels.There are a lot of pet shops in the area and a lot of residents out walking dogs, which they appear to be very fond of, but that doesn't extend to picking up after them. This, together with the atrocious condition of the sidewalks (predominantly paved with small tiles, which over time have become a shattered mess), makes walking around the neighbourhood a challenge to safety and hygiene.

Walked and Ate and Drank some Malbec. I loved Palermo--a great place for architecture lovers and people watchers. Nothing beats sitting outside on the sidewalk drinking aqua con gas and Malbec, eating fritas, and watching the day go by. Except maybe sitting outside on an upstairs balcony.
Nice trendy area... Lots of cafes, restaurants and little boutique shops. Check for my other reviews for recommendation of places..

OK to stay overnight. This area abundance in restaurants, especially Italian. There are not many grocery stores or cloths shops around. During daytime it may be a bit boring and at night dangerous. Especially the part after the railways.
My Favorite Barrio. Pa;ermo is definitely my favorite barrio (neighborhood) in buenos aires. full of cute little boutique shops, coffee places and restaurants
Bohemian and Cool. Lots of restaurantes, bars cool stores and great art galleries. It's heart is the Plaza Serrano, a small square very much alive with many nice clothes stores.
Where it's at!. This is Buenos Aires. Lots of shopping, restaurants, bars, ice cream, museums, etc. so much to do with gorgeous tree lined streets and fashionable ladies walking all around you.

Great area with fantastic restaurants and nightlife. We stayed in a boutique hotel in Palermo Hollywood. Great location and an easy walk to Palermo Soho. Fantastic shops, bars and restaurants. This is our favourite part of the city and would highly recommend. Great base for exploring. Lovely to wonder the neighbourhood and feels very safe.

Great spot in the city - bars, restaurants, shopping. It's a nice area and i'd definitely stay in this part of the city if i were to visit BA again. Lots of amenities nearby but it's a bit of a walk to subways. Buses seem harder to use in Argentina than Brazil, you'll need your walking boots on.
Trendy and Hip. This is a great spot to rent an apartment for a few days and have as a home base to explore the city. There are lots of nice shops and restaurants .

Pintoresque. Lovely area to walk around, shop as well if you wish, i would prefer the local stores than the world name stores, but that is just me, they have the loveliest things made by local "artists" from leather to clothing, you have to look for them (a few in J Luis Borges street very close to plaza Serrano) and some around there, a very big area but if you have the time go and stroll around.
Great area to hang out. I liked the restaurants and bars in the area. This is a nice trendy area that has a lot going on at night.
Too much to do!. Really convenient and enormous range of restarants and cafes, close to the Subte (d) and easy to get around.

Nice neighbourhood. Palermo is one of the most attractive neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires. A lovely area with restaurants, residential, business & commercial areas. Most highly recommended for a visit!

My homestay in the Palermo neighborhood of Buenos Aires, Argentina. Palermo is a great area to stay at. I had an amazing host mom in a nice apartment during my one-month study abroad over the summer. There is so much to do in the federal district and especially in the Palermo/Hollywood areas. Plenty of good restaurants, bars, and clubs. And tons of shops for miles on end. If you are looking for a place to stay in the capital city of Buenos Aires, I would definitely recommend Palermo. My apartment was super close to the subte, making it easier to get around, and only one stop away plus a short walk to the Universidad de Belagrano (University of Belgrano) where I had my Spanish class.

Lovely fashionable area. Really nice area to walk round in the daytime with street after street of stylish shops, fine restaurants and trendy bars. One section comes alive at night with bars and clubs. There's also an interesting street market in the square.

Off the beaten track in Palermo in Buenos Aires. What you need is one full day out of your busy schedule in Buenos Aires to fully comprehend and absorb the neighbourhood of Palermo. You need the full day actually to have three meals in three different classy restaurants, some good amount of time to walk around the blocks and a dedicated time exclusively to observe the people who can range from being stylish, to fashionable to outright outlandish. Think of approaching the exploration of this neighbourhood of Buenos Aires from the perspective of arts and not from science. What I mean to say is that do not follow rules, there are no theories or tips to tell you to start from point A and then take a right to eat at restaurant B and so on. You get the point right? You should have the right mindset to explore Palermo from the perspective of art so that it is abstract, it is very personal to you and subject to your own interpretation. From our experience of this fantastic part of the Argentine capital we will share a few discoveries we made which are worth sharing and chances are very strong you won’t find them in Lonely Planets travelogues.First was the serendipity of surrendering into the numerous aroma of Tealosophy. Secretly located between the Avenue Armenia and Gurruchaga, this place is the treasure island of all things tea! You will fall in love again with your sense of smell when you will enter into this place. Never before we discovered something like this. The shop itself is very cosy where the varieties of tea in pots are stacked neatly in the shelves. Spicy, Clementine, Darjeeling, Jasmine Flowers and many more permutation and combination of tantalising tea all under one roof. Don’t forget to buy a few cans of your favourite flavours as souvenirs. Just next to this place was an antics showroom called Paul & Co. Step in to get lost in time with carefully decorated vintage furniture, cutleries, beds and sofas. There was a strange mystery in this place. Both these places being next to each other and slightly inside hidden from the main roads in Palermo added to the extra intrigue of discovering them by chance and not by plan.Being amazed by these hidden gems in the neighbourhood, we stepped out to look for more such unique discoveries. We didn’t have to go that far as the Schlifka Molina gallery was just on the same road. This was a contemporary art gallery that represents and exhibits works of national and international artists, with the aim of making galleristic curatorial practice and experimentation as a practical platform to other fields. The way this gallery was designed and the artefacts displayed resonated very strongly the creative vibe of Argentina. You will have surely thought to visit national museums and galleries to know about Argentina’s past history but if you really want to know the story of the creative lot of Argentina and where the country is heading in terms of arts, you have to visit this gallery. Most notable here was the exhibition titled “El pájaro del brujo” — The bird of the witch — where the Argentine Vilar’s exhibition was striking, unusual, and unnerving in equal measure, drawing influence from Kenya Hara’s Japanese book of poetry “White”. The artefacts were strewn across the floor in a way making full use of the available space on the floor. It created as if a 3D experience of total immersion into the art. That was not the end there. Palermo is a true hotbed of creative genius. While walking randomly we then stood in front of the workshop and gallery of the Veron Mora- Morada. The way he has created his exhibits using day to day objects that will leave you in awe. You will have never thought of making a piece of art out of pencils, would you? Or what about nails? Other than getting struck by hammer to hang your photo on the wall, you will be surprised to see the same nails being used to create a piece of heart or something of artistic value, innovative we had to say. Palermo was one place in Buenos Aires where you will get to see clothing brands and retails outlets you will have not seen anywhere in the world. That meant that the brands were either local or regional and that increased their appeal. Boutique shops, designer showrooms all with pure Argentine roots and creativity were there for your discovery. Again, don’t rush in Palermo. Just wander around, take a pause and move on.
Wonderful place. I spent the vast majority of my time in Buenos Aires in Palermo. Lots of great restaurants, bars, places to shop, and landmarks.And I've never seen more beautiful women.

Trendy place. We stayed in Palermo Hollywood and strolled around Palermo Hollywood and Soho. Very safe till very late. Nice cafes with good food on every street. Open till very late. Don't get upset by the graffiti. It is an acceptable art form. Nice small shops selling everything from regular stuff, clothes, artifacts etc. Loved this part of town. Highly recommend.
Not so fun during the day. Considering where I'm from, it didn't look like a unique place to visit. Besides looking for restaurants, there is no much to do.

Good place to eat out. Good place for eating out. Great variety of restaurants on fits Roy street. But if you want to be sure to have a table it's better to book in advance. This place is place for a nightlife as well

Lovely ariea to stay and just walkaround. By Far Palermo is the most sympathetic neighborhood in Buenos Aires.It is full with restaurants and coffee house which always full with local people.It is not the most touristic area and not many attractions inside it (although you have the Botanic gardens and the zoo).Full with green gardens.excellent place to stay if you are coming for few days to tour the city.
Best area. Lovely safe area, lots of bars and restaurants to choose from. Felt very easy going and plenty of decent venues to sip away the evenings.
Its Like Greenwich Village. Thought I was in the East Village of NYC. Great walking Palermo ,i.e. Soho, Hollywood and Viejo. Great sophisticated shopping and dining.

Nice area. A quieter area away from the hustle and bustle of central BA. Nice tree lined streets with many upmarket shops and restaurants. However it wasn't quite as attractive as we thought it would be and prices were higher reflecting the touristy nature of the area. Nice to visit but I think there are better areas of BA to stay in.

Nice place to relax. Though we were only here for one night, at the end of 24 days in Argentina, it was a lovely place. Beautiful parks, lots of cafes and restaurants, and interesting neighborhoods to walk through. It's busy, with traffic, but a fun place to chill for a night or two.
PERFECT AREA. This area is the best! It is right near Recoleta and also a more trendy part called Palermo Soho. I felt so safe here and would never stay anywhere else in Buenos Aires!

A decent upscaleish part of Buenos Aires!. A decent upscaleish part of Buenos Aires! We were told that it was as nice as San Telmo ... but I did not enjoy the walk around the neighborhood on our trip to Buenos Aires in 2009 that much. It is just very posh and can be a bit pricey in regards to eats/shops ...

Restaurants and Night life abounds here.. From the Grand Hotel on Las Heras we took a taxi three times, twice to dine and on the last night in BA a Tango Show. Worth the drive, it reminded us of the East Village in New York.

Tourist trap. Our guided tour dropped us off at our tour guides favorite place. He sat at the bar drinking coffee while the ladies shopped in the shops. Looked like low quality items straight from China. Tango dancers on the corner waiting for pictures for a fee. JUNK.

Palermo. Very soughtafter place to stay, but in my opinion it is better to stay in the center of BsAs. A bit less safe, but a much more living place.Palermo is very residential and became very touristic

Nice unique boutiques. Palermo has nice unique boutiques and cafe's. It's a cute area. It is worth seeing. Dinner at Calden was great too. There are 2 new areas in Palermo (Soho & Hollywood). Soho was great, I have never been to Hollywood.
Coolest area of the city. Nice green space with people walking their dogs, outdoor markets, restaurants, boutique hotels - all in all a trendy area.
wander around. Another great little area to walk around. The architecture is amazing and beauty is everywhere. This is the rich part of town and it shows.

Lovely neighborhood. Best choice to stay in. Close enought to downtown. Plus, at night time you dont have to leave the neighborhood to find good restaurants and bars. It was the best think, coming back to the hotel from a long day walking to have a shower and have good options for the night just around the corner.
Great area. Lots of restaurants and shops. Felt very safe while walking around. Always people out and about, and very easy to find new places to try and hang out.
Stay here if you can.. Full of life and colour. A young spirit can be felt throughout the area. Lovely shops and restaurants. Great for walking and just soaking up the atmosphere.

Great Area to Spend your Buenos Aires Trip. Palermo is the place to stay if you want to stay in a trendy, restaurant filled location with lots to do at night. You cannot go wrong and if you like to explore you could find yourself walking around Palermo several days and not get bored.

A very nice area. with a lot of character! We spent most of our time in Argentina in Palermo (Hollywood and Soho) as well as near Plaza d' Italia. Enjoyed walking around everywhere. One major complaint I have is that the sidewalks need better maintenance. I fell down once due to the many holes and uneven ground spots everywhere.

The Place To Be. Palermo is a great place to be in Buenos Aires. It's full of parks, easily accessible by bus and within walking distance of many "must see" sites like the Recoleta Cemetery, Evita Museum, Japanese Gardens, and MALBA (Museo de Arte Latinamericano de Buenos Aires.
lovely boutiques and restaurants. Upscale area with lovely boutique style stores and cute restaurants. Wander around, do get lost and enjoy the outoor terraces.

Upscale elegance. Palermo is one of several languid, leafy and elegant upscale neighborhood outside of the center that are good for shopping, dining, galleries. I found them all pretty similar, but that is not a criticism. All easily reached by metro.

Great place for the urban explorer or foodie. Everything is very close to you, and the area comes alive, especially Friday to Sunday (but most nights) around 10-11pm. Practically no high rise buildings, only authentic charm.

Elegant shopping. Stayed in Palermo Viejo and had the best time. Could walk to everything, felt totally safe and could change and use American dollars. Dinners were cheap by Chicago standards and the beef was 100% much tastier than USA beef.

Night life. Palermo is where the best places to go out are.
You can find bars, restaurants, discos or just a nice coffee shop.
Nice place also if you want just go around and visit the street fairs or sit on a square.
Excelent neighbourhood. Walking around is a must here for you to know what this romantic neighbourhood can offer. Restaurants and museums are everywhere.

A great place to go if you enjoy having a good walk in a park, going to a good restaurant or enjoy a Tango Show.. I love Palermo's night's life with so many restaurants and Tango Shows to choose from, and if you like to dace "milonga", well, this is the place to go

Palermo Viejo. Enjoyed a lunch and bought a few vinyl tango records here. On a spring afternoon, it was very pleasant with a very relaxed atmosphere: shopping, architecture, outdoors market, coffee shops, people watching. The opposite of downtown Buenos Aires.

Very at home. 5 days staying in the neighborhood were very relaxing and entertaining. Though warned about the level of minor crime (in Buenos Aries overall), I never felt anything but warmth for the people of this neighborhood.

Live, drink, eat and enjoy. One of the wealthier neighbourhoods of Buenos Aires, Palermo is rich in nice restaurants (try the amazing steaks at Don Julio!), bars, clubs in a relaxed atmosphere, close to some of the beautiful parks of the city. A good place to stay while you're visiting the city!

Visit the Armenian cultural centre for some Tango classes.. For my entire stay in BA I lived in Palermo with my friends, besides being a very safe area it has a lot of lovely small shops to stroll by. We spent an evening at the Armenian cultural Centre which offers a big variety of dancing classes throughout the week - we chose Tango and even though we had never done it before it was great. By the end of the day there is also open floor for everyone to practice their steps, and sometimes even a professional show. All for around 60 pesos.

Great night life. Over Palermo you will find a lot of bar, pubs and restaurants. This is a great place to be at night you have a great night life and it seems that the party never ends here.
It is full of places to go to eat and enjoy a nice meal. Also you have the zoo and the Rosedal over there.

just a fashion place. a funky place , fashionable , design , mode, restaurants ,bars , night clubs
boutiques for fashion
old neiborhood been rebamped

Laid-back, Bohemian neighborhood. This neighborhood was a break away from the rest of the tourist attractions in Buenos Aires. I sat down in a café near Plaza Serrano to enjoy a nice local lunch, relax, and enjoy the atmosphere. For awhile, I actually forgot I was in South America because it reminds me of the more trendy neighborhoods found in New England cities.

Hipster and fun. Art, design, cool and beautiful people. Here is where art lives in Buenos Aires. If you are a cultural person, the Palermo is your hood to adore. Best restaurants, bars. And during the day you can enjoy the huge amount of boutiques and top brands to shop and become a fan of argentinian design. 100% recommended!

Trending Neighbourhood. In palermo you can find the most trending places from Buenos AiresIt has several different spots. Palermo Soho, which is similar to NYC SoHoPalermo Hollywood, which is similar to Chelsea Market and NYC Soho, but more suitable for having dinner, lunch, drinks or night life.You can find also "los Bosques de palermo" Which is a great park similar to central park in NYC.
Lovely neighborhood. It's my favorite neighborhood in Buenos Aires. I love the atmosphere and the streets. It's nice to just walk around and admire the houses and architecture.
Great to hang out. This is the place where all people go to meet up before a night out ! just having a drink outside in the place was awsome !

Fun and trendy part of town. Buenos Aires has many quality neighbourhoods and this is one of the better ones - great parks and gardens , Zoo and some of the better restaurants - easy to get to no matter where you staying and taxis are so cheap.
Cool neighborhood. - Trendy neighbourhood- A bit hit by year of populist government in Argentina...could be much better in a healthy economic environment
Great town!. Great town to stay at if you're visiting Buenos Aires! It's close to everything practically! You have a lot of restaurants, bars, nightclubs, and more. Very practical

PALERMO A PLACE TO VISIT. Palermo is not only the lakes, or the Casino, is also the neighborhood, is fancy, the parks are incredible nice , the lakes, the Japones Garden, fantastic, the ZOO, the Botanic Garden...a place to visit
Great location to stay in BA. Location and food nearby were all excellent. Go to Don Julio for dinner, it's brilliant ................

Best restaurants in BA. Great spot for a bite to eat.. you have so much choice here.. Just a fantastic vibe, great little places, as well as the bigger BBQ joints as well. Great to stroll around, nice apartments and shops, but definitely go here to get authentic Argentinian and a BA feel..
Excellent neighborhood. Loved the area surrounded by parks, very European and clean. Palermo Soho has great shops, and Palermo Hollywood has great restaurants.

Not impressed. I been staying here at Palermo for two months now and I am NOT so impressed. Sure there are many restaurants, overpriced shops and TOO MANY PEOPLE. Side walks ARE HORRIBLE!!!! They are so bad that I fell the first day I went out and ended up in ER. I been told by locals that "locals" go to hospital very often for the same reason - falling down on a bed streets/sidewalks. So many people are just rushing by each other clenching their purses/begs and looking at the ground just so they too don't end up in the ER.

Palermo. Lived in Palermo Soho for 4 months. The area is a mixture of cultures like most of BA. Good for transport, shopping, eating out. Near enough to central BA but far enough out to be secure. Good for the Aeroparque, Racetrack, casino, zoo, japanese garden, metro etc. Enjoyed it. A good base to explore Argentina, Chile and S.Brazil.

European-style getaway. Lovely area which does have a nice soho feel to it. Not cheap, but some interesting shops and cute cafes. I also hired a scooter here from the GreenScooter.net which was super fun!
Amazing neighborhood. The most beautiful and chicky neighborhood in Buenos Aires.This is the place to go shopping and eating in the best restaurants and coffee shops.
Just awesome!. Great restaurants. Great clubs. Great atmosphere. Great place. If you're in Buenos Aires, you should definately be aiming to stay here.

Beautiful neighborhood. Palermo is a low density neighborhood close to Buenos Aires' downtown. You'll find many coffee shops, restaurants, stores, art galleries and plazas. Many of Buenos Aires' best restaurants are in Palermo. If you just want a calm place to walk, relax and see interesting stuff without all the city's fuzz, this is the place.

Great upscale neighborhood!. Get away from the hustle and bustle of downtown BA. Escape to this huge part of town with upscale shops for window shopping, museums, and huge avenues. It must be the newest part of Buenos Aires bc it appears to be the most cared for.
Not sure what the fuss is about. Completely unimpressed with what is basically a touristy flee market...we had to check we were really at the right place...waste of time.

Would enjoy staying here on next visit. On a full day tour of Buenos Aires, we traveled through and around the Palermo area. It is full of wonderful restaurants and lots of activity. Would probably stay in that area on our next visit.
Great part of city. Lots of good shopping, restaurants, bars, people watching, and beautiful parks. Good place to see how locals live. Close to everything by subway or taxi. Nice people.

The best in town. Palermo has everything people attracts to trendy, unusual shops, cozy corners, great - i said: great - restaurants, lively people..... It has a west-coast kind of feel like san francisco. Dont miss resto Dada on place serrano.
My favorite part of BA. Nicer to walk around than Centro or even Recoleta - lots of nice cafés, fun bars, and neat stores to explore. Great vibe on the street, even in winter.
Great shopping!. I loved walking around this bustling area. The shopping was Excellant especially for beautiful leather purses at Humawaca!
A cool place to spend day and night. With old houses and new shops, from good restaurants to street markets, you will find everything in this lovely restored part of Buenos Ayres.
Nice restaurants. You will find great restaurants over there, better option than in Porto Madero. Make sure you reserve a table at Osaka or Tegui and you won't regret!

Unique and convenient. We rented an apartment for a week here and were very happy with the location. Our apartment was very quiet because it faced the back and there were no noisy businesses nearby. Be careful of your location because if you are near a supermarket or large business or a club, it can be very noisy. The neighborhood was very unique and artsy, with small boutiques lining the streets. We were close to the Botanical Gardens and zoo, as well as the subway. There are two lovely plazas filled with wonderful restaurants and a weekend market. We felt safe walking around at any time, but watch where you step. There are lots of dogs in the neighborhood!

Nice neighborhood for the young!. The up side is that it is easy to rent an apartment , walk to a grocery store and restaurants. The downside is that you should be younger than 35. The noise on the street went until 3:30 am. Very cute boutiques aimed at a youthful market.

Great area to stay. We stayed at Hotel Fierro in Soler St in Palermo Hollywood
Felt comfortable and easy walking distance to Subway D
The subway is easy to manage and takes you to areas of historic significance such as Casa Rosada and Congresso
I would recommend staying in this area

Beautiful Neighborhood. Palermo is one of the best spots in BA for shopping and dining. We didn't stay here (we AirBnB'd an apartment in San Telmo) but we did spend at least two days of our trip wandering around its pretty streets.

A great way to spend our last day. As 2 couples traveling together we decided to spend our last day (Saturday afternoon before a red-eye flight) walking around Palermo. The vendors were great and the products were fun to look at. We ended up with a painted bar sign and our friends picked up a gorgeous painting! Beware of pigeons! We sat down for lunch and had a flurry of pigeons all around us.

Full of stylish bars and restaurants. and therefore unfortunately by far more expensive than the other districts of Buenos Aires. As lots of people enjoy strolling around during nighttime and going from one café to the next, this is quite a safe place. However, everything looks quite uniform.

A mixed review. Palermo used to be a nice place with small bars and coffeehouses with plenty of boheme people, university students and professors discussing, reading and smoking in fornt of a cup of good coffee. Since the late 1990s it has been invaded by well-known brands and outlets. The bars and beatiful restaurants are still there and it has an excellent night life.

Something for everyone. Picking a district to sleep in such a huge city has a its challenges. I’m glad I called this home base. You walk the streets and feel like you are part of the neighborhood. You don’t see tourist traps, you’ll find something for everyone taste.

Great Neighborhood for 4 nights. Palermo is like everything you hear. Understated neighborhood with lots and lots of small boutiques and cafes. No matter what your food choice is, you will find something to your liking in Palermo. I wouldn't want to spend a week in Palermo, but 4 nights was perfect. As nice as Palermo is, make sure you get out to other neighborhoods like San Telmo, Villa Crespo, and Recoleta. Palermo is more taxi friendly than Metro friendly, so budget a little money for taxis to other places in BA. A Subte (metro) stop is available on the edge of Palermo, but after walking all day in other areas we always took a cab back home rather than walk another 12 blocks from the metro.

Awesome Buenos Aires!!. I think Palermo is one of the most beautiful city! Its clean , super friendly, very unique , wonderful to walk and see the beautiful buildings and little cafe's , people go out of the way to help you!!Will love to live in a place like this!!!

Ahhhh! to Be Young!. Palermo is fun. It's much more fun if you're young. There are young people everywhere, doing everything. This translate into energy. Palermo is a lively, energetic place with really fun, vibes that just engulfs you. People are friendly, interesting, interested and willing to help you find the "happenings". It's difficult to be bored in Palermo. Whether you're grocery shopping, at a laundromat, at the bar, at the salon - just being out in Palermo is a feel good activity!

Palermo Soho or Hollywood - it´s all good!. this is a hip area with great shops, restaurants, bars and just loads of interesting things to catch your eye. From upscale leather for divine riding boots to cool little boutique hotels (like the Faera) there is something for everything.

Best neighborhood for younger travelers. This is a very hip neighborhood, favorite in BA. There are lots of the top restaurants in this area. Nightlife is great, many many bars and tango clubs. The shopping is very good here too, lots of little shops that are fun to peak in.

Gentrified towards boring. We stayed in Palermo a week and in it's favour it has plenty of shops (boutique), bars and some of the only green space to be found in BA (still has 12 lanes of traffic running through but a good place to jog once you get off the main road & do a few figure 8s). It's very safe at night, well lit, well policed & has good transport links. It's also a bit soulless. Palermo Soho is a poor mans Soho - smacks of trying too hard, Palermo parks is full of city slicker crash pads & dead at the weekends. When you go to San Telmo and see people drinking, dancing, drumming and trading in the streets you realise how lacking in pulse Palermo is.
Our favorite. We stayed in Recoleta based on many recommendations but going back we'd stay in Palermo. Much more action and more alive. Recoleta is like the Upper East Side, Palermo is Village/Soho.

a bit run down, expensive shops. It's either - or; we were there on a rainy day and believe me, BA and Palermo are not very nice then. The restaurants were pretty empty and the nice shops scattered. We walked up and down various side streets and simply couldn't grow warm. We also observed that whenever something was to our liking, they didn't seem to have our size...
Excellent neighbourhood. We stayed in the area for few days ,great restaurants , safe to walk , easy trasportation , nice houses .

Bohemian area of BA. My Dad and I spent a day walking around Palermo. We walked from the subway station, I believe it was the Plaza Italia and then weaved up the roads into the central parts of Palermo. They center has a beautiful square with restuarants, bars, and artisan market. There´s lot of chic shopping. Cheaper than big shopping in NYC, London, or Paris, but it was all expensive for BA standards. We didn´t buy anythign. but window shopping was fun.
one of the best places in BA. Nice shops, bars, pubs and restaurants. Easy to walk around and discover Buenos Aires. very similar like Soho in NY
A "Mateo" carriage to ride like royalty..... These parks are beautiful on their own, just to walk around. But if you want to spice it up, rent a Mateo carriage and ride around like royalty...
Trendy, safe city. I felt safe anytime I walked on the street in the subte (subway). Lots of shops and tons of places to see within walking distance.
Honeymoon and 1st Anniversary. It was an awesome area to stay at with many restaurants, coffee bars, nightclubs, shopping stores and just a very pleasant and safe area to hang out and relax in.

Walking, eating, drinking , shopping. Great place for just walk around. Full of surprises like great Cafes, restaurants , pubs and clubs . Also very good for shopping. On saturday there is a market on Plaza Serrano , which I liked much better then San Telmo market . You can´t miss it
Charming neighborhood. This is one of my fave areas in Buenos Aires. The area is very trendy and is lined by gorgeous cafe, bars, shops and restaurants, creating a bohemian feel of the area.
My favorite party of the city!. This area was very cute and calm. I loved the shopping and cafes. Ended up staying the whole day wondering Palermo.
Lovely neighborhood. I loved this neighborhood with lots of cafes, restaurants, beautiful people. Friendly environment. Feels like Europe and United States mix with the spanish flair.

Palermo is the place to stay when you visit Buenos Aires. We stayed at the great Abode B&B in Palermo. Could not have been a better location.
Just a great mix of restaurants and shops and low rise housing for residents of Buenos Aires.
Stay in Palermo to get the vibe of Buenos Aires where the up and coming young people live with their families.

More tempting then the downtown. We loved walking in the streets and the boutiques were nice. The park Rosedal was wonderful. Since is was Easter, there were people all over, skating, sykling, walking, running and relaxing.

Palermo Day/Night. I arrived at my hotel on Gorriti st in Palermo soho.This particular block had no resemblance to soho NY. On one side of the block was a woodworking shop and an open parking lot for cars on the other side was an old supermarket an auto repair shop and an empty lot all within a half a block from a railroad crossing some stray dogs and 1 or 2 homeless.I was assured it was safe and it was ! however it was not a picturesque block. I then went out and about and discovered the area does have a certain charm about it even with all the broken sidewalks.Daytme is quiet and a lot of businesses are closed except for the clothing boutiques and art galleries,most restaurants open later.Nighttime is when soho comes alive with a good choice of bars/restaurants and outdoor cafes.There is a visible police presence,however I did not have any safety concerns but as a tourist I remain alert.Palermo is great at night but I prefer Recoleta In the day.

Trendy. Fashion, innovation and creativity characterize this renewed neighbourhood that has turned into an avant-garde design mecca.Visit its different sections to get a full picture. Your shopping time will be guaranteed.

The place to visit!. Palermo is adorned with boutique designer stores, hair salons and the best coffee shops / restaurants. Perfect for wandering around and enjoying Buenos Aires life. Much more upmarket than other areas.

The largest green spot in BA. Although threatened by many people eager to built buildings, this large park designed by Carlos Thays in 1920, is one of the most beautiful places in BA. It holds a lake, a golf course, a large Tennis Stadium and many places just to sit down and relax.
nice area. We stayed at Palermo and we were really pleased.The place offers nice hotels,restaurants,shops and places to visit.

Eating and Drinking. Amazing area to go for a night out, so many restaurants and bars to choose from. Keep in mind that a lot of the locals will not go out for dinner until 9-10pm (restaurants don't usually open until 8pm) and if you go to a club they don't start getting good until 12pm onwards.

The Place to Go. Palermo is the hippest neighborhjood in the city and we quickly saw why that is the case. the architecture is nice but it is much more the cafes and bars and restaurants spread throughout the city that make it so special. Had a great meal out and then went for drinks at a cheap but cool spot. Lots of life during the day and night
Lively Atmosphere, Lots of Fun. A meandering maze of restaurants, bars, and shops. Full of gorgeous scenery and gorgeous people. One of my favorite places.

Trip to Buenos Aires. We just spent 12 days in Buenos Aires and rented an apartment in Palermo for an excellent price. Palermo was a nice place to be; good neighboorhood restaurants, a large supermarket, the metro all very close, close to nice parks and a little quieter than the center of Buenos Aires.

Trendy. Our hotel was in this part of town, so we did a lot of focusing on this area during our evenings. There are so many great restaurants and shops. We found this location quite nice for starting each one of our ventures to see other areas of Buenos Aires. It would be a hard decision to decide where to spend your nights, but we always found so much activity and so many amazing stops in this area. A young and hip place to be at night.

Fun and interesting area to stay. We had a loft apartment in Palermo for 4 days and enjoyed being part of this trendy, fashionable area. Lots of great clothes shops and smart restaurants as well as umpteen pizza/snack bars in Plaza Serrano. Sadly the graffiti diminishes the overall experience.

Great Neighborhood. Located in easy reach of major attractions. Happening residential neighborhood but with great shopping areas within walking distance. Many great restaurants in the neighborhood. We felt perfectly safe.

Beautiful. Very nice Bars and Restaurants. lots of nice shops, wich are open till late. Definetly a place for young and hip people. When you are in Buenos Aires you have to go there. It´s a must do in BA. But be always aware of pickpockets.

hip area. liked all the cute shops(young adult clthes…nothing worth buying, but fun to look at) and tons of cute restaurants…good bar scene esp at plaza ... loved outdoor flea market on sunday,,,don't bother with Recoleta's

Busy, humming place. This is a semi-historic, semi-modern with style neighborhood. Many shops, restaurants, bars with street seating. You can hardly go wrong. Also look for chef restaurants like Tegui and "closed door" restaurants. These places are for foodies. Menu changes daily and each dish is to die for. All for under $100 with wine. A similar dinner would run 5 - 10 times that in NYC, LA or SF

nice area to shop. We walked there from La Recoleta. It was a busy area with a European feel (which we prefer). Lots of shops restaurants and cafes. Great deals and a safe vibe. Walked down the main Avenida Santa Fe to arrive downtown at Calle Florida which is a traffic free boulevard stretching about 10 blocks until ending at the government buildings. Great combo walking tour.

The Best Neighbourhood in Buenos Aires. If you tend to like visiting a new city but can be overwhelmed with the hustle and bustle (like me) you will enjoy staying in Palermo. With the highest number of restaurants, cafes and bars per capita, Palermo neighbourhood offers plenty of dining and drinking options without the crazy crowds and with added peace and quiet from a lack of major traffic. Palermo Hollywood is a little quieter and the bars and restaurants are a little more trendy and upscale, but Palermo Soho has a stronger variety of quaint cafes and many bohemian dining options as well. Both districts have many outdoor dining options, and with the somewhat lazy traffic and wide streets it is comfortable to enjoy a meal or drinks on the patio. If you are able to endure the sweaty metro (subte) or willing to spring for a taxi, staying in Palermo offers a more relaxing experience with easy access to the microcenter if you're looking for a larger tourist crowd (although, majority of great discos and bars are still in Palermo so technically, you never need to leave).

Palermo is looking seedy. I have spent much time in Buenos Aires over the years- nearly a year in total, and this is the first time I've seen Palermo look like crap. It's covered in graffitti, and many stores are closed. I was shocked to see it in such a dirty state of disrepair. The whole place looks worn out.
staying in palermo. Vibrant café society where people are still up at 5 in the morning. Bars and café open all night, even an ice cream parlour open at midnight.

Greenwich Village meets Barcelona. Trendy, safe but with a little bit of edge, all sorts of shops and huge variety of bars and restaurants. A perfect combination. This is a relatively new up and coming area which can happily fill your days and nights
Great place to walk around. Good restaurants and cafes, tree lined streets, lots of graffiti and be careful when crossing the street, drivers are aggressive and do not wait for pedestrians

Loved this Hippie Market. picked up many unique artisan gifts for back home. Its a taxi ride from most places, but well worth it. tons of places to eat and drink, you can easily spend a day, or just an hour.

Soho Palermo - Good Neighborhood. This is a very nice middle class neighborhood. We went there to go to dinner at La Carabara. We went early to walk the shops and see the neighborhood. Lots of cute places and bars to have a drink before dinner.

Nice bars restaurants night life. Had an afternoon here and was pleasantly surprised.It has several areas ( squares ) so decide which you prefer beforehand,some are bars some are shops and some are more nightlife,but all are nice

Good fun in this fashion center. We enjoyed strolling on two different days in Palermo. One part, Viejo, is older (of course by its name) and has a bit of the grotty up-and-coming stylish mode about it. The newer part, with Ave Santa Fe running through it is much more brash and commercial. Good place to find something to eat, particularly on the streets around Honduras Street.

Palermo Soho/Viejo is THE place. This is a great area to base your stay. There are tons of cute shops and cafes. The atmosphere is hip and relaxed. You can spend a few days exploring and not get bored. For my money, this is the best place in Buenos Aires. Although, avoid Palermo Hollywood, it's too bland and boring there.

Great walking day. We enjoyed walking the district, the architecture and peaceful parks. During the day we experienced some of the cafes and the local Argentinean beer and hospitality. Graffiti too much of, and "poop and scoop" or the lack of, is a major problem in all parts of BA.

Upper class neighbourhood. It has many sections to visit. Many shopping areas, Hard Rock cafe, china town, museums, including Evita museum. Must at least drive around and see the neighbourhood if you don't have time to explore on foot.
beautiful. A must see. Beautiful parks including the lovely japanese park. The large open flower sculpture is gorgeous. So many tennis clubs if you partake. Very green area
Green and walkable. Palermo is a very livable part of Buenos Aires. Near to the "subte", full of restaurants and boutique hotels, the area reminds me of Paris.
Nightlife. If you want to go out at night, this is the place to walk around. There are dozens of restaurants and bars, at all price levels and for any kind of food.

Living in Palermo was the right thing for us. We arrived in November 2013 and left in January 2014. Except for 11 days in Patagonia, Palermo became our home away from home. highly commendable neighborhood.

Palermo - gentrified. Palermo Soho is the place to be if you are young and want an upmarket but grungy area. This was a poor area which has become gentrified. It is full of little shops, bars, cafes and restaurants. It is well serviced by public transport.

A complete neighboorhood. This neighborhood is full of restaurants, bars, discos, fashion clothing stores, flea market, handcraft fair, parks, Japanese Garden and many more.
It is good to enjoy the area walking around or using a bike.

Cute area!. This is a wonderful area of Buenos Aires. It's more residential, and a little more quiet. It's further away from some attractions, but I suggest staying in that area over staying in El Central.
Safe but not too exciting. We stayed in Palermo Soho at an outstanding hotel. However when it came to visiting Palermo we did not come accross anything earth shattering.
Nice area. Very charming area. Good shopping and restaurants.Felt much less touristiqe than the San Telmo area promoted by the guidebooks.

Why do entire districts qualify as 'attractions'. I've lived in Palermo temporarily for 2 months now - near (Scalabrini and Santa Fe) - So I may be missing something here, but... why do entire districts qualify as 'attractions'? Ok, so you are less likely to get mugged or shot in Palermo than some other places, and it has some good restaurants, bars, and parks, but surely each of those attractions/places should be reviewed individually and deserve individual recognition...What's next? Will we be reviewing entire countries as 'attractions'??In my opinion, Palermo is a nice area of Buenos Aires to live/visit, but it isn't what I would class as an attraction, or landmark, like Machu Picchu, or the Obelisk... its just a nice area of BA where regular and everyday people live and work.

Just a grotty concrete jungle!. Smog, cars, stupid people walking in the way ALL THE TIME, nothing but shops and bars and restaurants. Dog poo all over the pavements, air-con dripping everywhere, and graffiti. I don't know why people rave about it so much.
Best area for evening drinks with Bohème Flair. The area is called Palermo Soho in reference to NY.Lost of chic clothes shops and bars and restaurants.Best place for a night out!

The cool place to hang out in Buenos Aires. Lots going on in this neighborhood (Palermo Soho and Palermo Hollywood). You can walk for hours to see high end chain shops and artsy local shops, sidewalk cafes, bistros, and chic dining stops. Plus some of the best boutique hotels in the city are here. Close to Aeroparque Airport too. And while you can walk anywhere in the area, it's easy to get a taxi. Have fun, enjoy, but also be aware of your surroundings as petty robbery is not uncommon.
Great area. The really great restaurants are here. I have learnt to avoid Puerto Madera after eating a few of the sub-standard restaurants there.

Great place to make your home base. Stayed at a rental home on Arevalo Street and walked everywhere - so many great shops and even better restaurants! We were no more than a 20 minute cab ride from every where else we wanted to go. . .

Average. Big city standard area. We weren't particularly impressed that this was a place we needed to see and experience. The area is nice for Buenos Aires but as said previously we wouldn't make a special trip for it.

Beautiful Quarter of B.A.. Rented a great apartment and wandered around the up-and-coming residential areas and streets and courtyards filled with lovely cafes, bakeries and stores. Paseo de Rosedal park is gorgeous with its myriad of roses and ponds and birds.

Huge neighbourhood. Palermo is one of the biggest neighbourhoods in Buenos Aires, so you should pick a specific area before you get down there. It has shopping areas, parks and much night life. It´s very nice and chances are you´ll spend more than just one day there.

Amazing area and people. Palermo is a great area to stay, you could spend your time just there, but why? You are in BA!Use the Subte to explore this amazing city, pocket change will take you to all corners. Rent bikes, use the bike lanes. And did I mention wines for the same you'd spend on your latte at home?Finally you HAVE to hook up with Mariano for free walking tours BA from Teatre Colon daily, highly recommended. (Just remember to tip Oz)

THE neighbourhood in Buenos Aires. If you go to Buenos Aires and don't have much time to go everywhere, make sure you take time to visit the Palermo Barrio. Great streets, great shops, clean, safe and pleasant to walk around in...

Late but comparable review. We stayed in Palermo Hollywood for one months in a lovely apartment(loft) in October/November 2012, we enjoyed the area with fine restaurants, fast food and the famous Santa Fe street with many shops and the supermarket Koto. Many buses are nearby to take you anywhere also the subte is available. The zoo is in the area also many parks and gardens are close. This year 2013 we hired an apartment at micro center very close to the obelisk, at September/October for one month. Although we enjoyed our stay at Palermo last year but from our new experience this year we recommend staying in Micro center for one more important reason which is to save many bus trips ( although bus fare is not expensive at all but bus trips are time and effort consuming) . We loved Palermo and we loved more Micro Center.

Nice part of the city. That´s where we the nicest neighborhoods of Buenos Aires are. In between Palermo and Recoleta you will find lots of green areas and nice residences and interesting stores.It´s very different from the central part and we found excellent restaurants and coffee shops.A little overpriced if you choose to stay there.

Fun and Vibrant Neighbourhood. A fun and vibrant, young vibe. We spent an afternoon and evening here. There were a few hidden gems where we got a bargain but for the most part, many shops were out of our price range. Still a great day of shopping or window shopping. Many great restaurants and cafes. Check out plaza Serano. The area really comes alive at night. A fun place for dinner and drinks.

Fun way to spend an afternoon. We're staying downtown and took the green line to Plaza Italia. Stay in bed till midday and take your time... we arrived in the market area around 3 pm and saw people messing about with market tables - we thought they were packing up - as it turns out, just setting up! The restaurants at Plaza Serrano are quite possibly very good - god knows they're popular. If you eat two or three blocks away, staff will coddle you and the prices are waaay better (see review of Magdalena's) - Anyway - lots of chic shops, many gorgeous art nouveau buildings, diabolical footpaths but that just proves you're in BA. Really nice way to spend a crisp, sunny, winter's afternoon. And remember - the metro is only $2.50 peso per trip - less than US$0.50. Get out there and resist the urge of the concierge to taxi everywhere....

Convenient Access to Transportation. I stayed in Palermo for 5 days. It has easy access to the Subte (metro), buses, and taxis. Plenty of places to eat and even groceries stores in the event want to cook at your place. I found the convenience of buying at Cotto Supermarket, especially junk food and breakfast items. There is also a Claro cell company for your cellular needs in the event you carry your unlock phone with you. There is a bank and plenty of stores to shop. What really threw me off was the condition of the sidewalks and the general appearance of the place. Most of the sidewalks are cracked, there is trash and graffiti everywhere. Do not understand why the government makes the owners of the business clean their store front and have someone clean up the cracked sidewalks. It is suicidal for females to walk on high heels. In regards to the graffiti I was told by the taxi driver that the graffiti was due the free expression that most Argentinians enjoy today as oppose to the times when Argentinians were suppressed to congregated and stand in the corners to smoke a cigarette. I do not really know what are the causes to this problem, nevertheless the graffiti , the trash and the cracked sidewalks are there to stay.

One of the better neighborhoods in Buenos Aires for tourists. Palermo has several different sections (Soho, Viejo, Hollywood, etc.). Collectively these neighborhoods are know as Palermo. Most foreign tourists would do better to stay in Palermo than downtown or in another part of Buenos Aires. The streets are generally safer, and there is generally more that can be done without taking a taxi (e.g., shopping, eating, etc.). Be forewarned, however, that the sidewalks in Palermo, as in the rest of Buenos Aires, are a crumbling mess, and that trash and graffiti are everywhere. In other words, a stay in Palermo is not like a visit to Miami or London.

Some of the Best Shops in the City. When one refers to BA as a city of designers, he is probably referring to Palermo. Boasting some of the best labels and designers in BA, the chic and fashionable Palermo never fails to delight with one-of-a-kind shops, swanky boutiques and great cafes. Some of the city's best-loved designers and most sought-after foreign brands can be found here. So bring you purse and start shopping!

Drink all night party all day... Met some amazing people in this great little spot in BA a little away from the madness of downtown. A great spot to get everywhere you need to. Nothing like having supper at 10 pm and drinking ice cold (cheap) beer all night to shock your senses and really make you feel abroad. All in all met friends for life in Palermo and would recommend it highly as a place to stay.

Can't experience BA without visiting Palermo. No trip to BA I complete without visiting Palermo. It would be like going to San Francisco and skipping Fishermans Wharf and New York and missing Times Square. It is colorful and original and works hard to provide a positive experience. Be wary as police are located around the perimeter of the area. Our tour guides made it very clear that we should not return after dark. The shops are interesting and it is simply fun to walk around Palermo.
Love Palermo. All the areas of Palermo are quite lovely. Great place just to stroll and enjoy the pretty streets, little houses, great restaurants, shops, cafes, parks, etc.

Colourful, interesting, some nice restaurants. Good for people watching, has many trendy shops as well as some cheaper ones. There is a small market square with lots of interesting souvenirs and artisan items. Good for browsing and just enjoying a nice day. Lots of bars, cafes a very live.y and colourful place. Some of the more popular Buenos Aires restaurants are to be found there too. It would be a real shame to miss this lovely Neighbourhood. Seems like a b.? Yuppie place

Best night time neighbourhood in BA. Palermo is the best neighbourhood for both night time partying / dinner with friends and also during the day to do some shopping. Excellent neighbourhood. Very well done and classy finish. Definitely get yourself there during your stay in BA.
nice shopping aerea. not to crowded and good lifestyle shops around trendy shops aswell, nice shopping atmosphere. dont forget to deal....
Great neighborhood. Palermo is a lovely area with lots of cafes, restaurants and little shops. Nice parks and enough security to make it a safe and clean place to wander and enjoy.

Great place to go shopping.... And a great place to stay and eat and walk around...If you ask, there is a section of Palermo that has outlet shopping. Everything is a lot more expensive than you would imagine but there are deals. Look for the Argentinian brands as imports are heavily taxed. Great night life and also great to walk around during the daytime. Cafes and lots to do and see. People watch. Walkable from Downtown but best take the subway. Easy and efficient and cheap.

The friendliest, greenest and best area of the city.. Wonderful area. Perfect for wondering about in and getting a sense of 'true' Buenos Aires. The are some lovely restaurants, bars and shops centred around the two plazas in Palermo Soho and some excellent restaurants can be found on the first 3 streets of Palermo Hollywood from Humboldt up.

The leafy barrio!. Love Palermo and all of it's areas! There are lots of good restaurants, weekend markets, and shops in the various parts of Palermo. The green space really sets Palermo apart, though, and that's what's best and most enjoyed about this part of the city.
Great hood. I loved wandering the streets of Palermo with funky stores and nice places to eat and drink and just watch the people stroll by. Nice area to stay in compared to other parts of city.
wonderful walking neighborhood. cafes good restaurants, friendly people and we saw a free concert in the park. had a cafe after dinner in very romantic setting.

Nice huge neighbourhood. Palmero is a huge neighbourhood broken up into several sub districts. It has a very nice vibe to it with plenty of shopping and dining options. One of the great features are the splendid large parks including the botanical gardens (free entry). The zoo is also in palmero and the entry fee is about US/AUS $10.
Creativity Abounds.. Palermo is a fabulous feast of creativity... including funky fashion, delicious food and sultry tango. Great for shopping, eating and dancing.

Very nice and special area for a walk and coffee break. When you visit this area be sure it is a time shops will be open and had people around. Very nice area and the houses architecture reminds you the villages of Spain

Cool area of Buenos Aires, lots of activities and restaurants. It is a very good location to stay as a tourist on your visit to Buenos Aires.
Palermo has a lot of the traditional aspects of BsAs that you want to see, mixed with a lot of restaurants, walking areas, parks, shopping.
Don´t miss Plaza Serrano for a special cultural experience
Las Heras Park on a Sunday. the park was filled with people juggling, sunbathing, palyin guitars, picnicing -- mostly in their twenties. A great palce to meet locals.

Trendy district bars and restaurants, shops and design. Formerly a quiet 1900s residential district, home of author Jorge Luis Borges, it is now a vibrant district open 24/7, with bars, restaurants and trendy design shops. Close to Santa Fe Avenue worth visiting in the evenings and weekends.
Great area. This area of the city has so much to do, so many shops, and food. I found this area of the city to be very new york like and the people are so friendly.

Palermo soho keeps the only real soho personality in the world. If you go to London or New York soho's the ambience is already very upscale and nor hip or young any more. Palermo Soho still has that. this neighborhood entails local designers, an inmnse variety of world food, discount shopping, great cafes adn one of the most amazing Graffiti displays in the world. Plaza Julio Cortazar bars and restaurants turn ito a market for the weekend. Restaurants there are excellent recommend Osaka and La cabrera.
Best place too shop in BA. Palermo was just the best place to shop in BA. Nice cafees, calm threes and a big variation in shops.

Three Weeks in Palermo, Soho.. Safe, fun, great food, trendy,etc... While Recoleta still receives all the referrals Palermo was for us a better representation of what Argentina was really like. Neighborhood bars, trendy resturants, convienent to parks, zoo, and transportation. In three weeks we did not see or hear of any criminal activity. If you get as far as BA don't make the mistake and not go the Iguazu Falls. One word "breathtaking". Empanada's where a great snack/meal treat when you tired of the Lomo in the high end eateries. If you haven't been warned Split the portions of meat. Your still likely not to finish it all. We used vrbo to rent our apartment. We were very happy.

Where to Live in Buenos Aires for longer than a week. Palermo SohoThe most important decision to make if you are staying for more than a week is where to live. We have been to Buenos Aires four times and each time stayed in different places Congresso, Recoleta, and San Telmo. Each area has a certain charm but the best place we have stayed is Palermo Soho. We rented two different apartments in the areaIt is a suburb away from the heart of Buenos Aires but easily accessible on the D line from the Plaza Italia stop. It is hip, interesting, safe but above all the food is wonderful. I had never had a really good meal in Buenos Aires until I found Palermo. We would go out each lunch and dinner to a different restaurant and were rarely disappointed. Neighbouring Palermo Hollywood has abundant and good restaurants. Our favourite restaurants were Freud and Fahler. The lunch menu (3 courses from 18 pesos) is great. We walked by Don Julio's every day and thought it was another 'meat' place even though the food looked good. By the time we ate there it was the day before we were to leave and we ended up eating the rest of our meals there. Another favourite is Cluny. But there are lots of supermercado if you want to cook your own meal. Eventually we missed foods with spice.What I liked about Palermo was it was quiet compared to Congresso or San Telmo. The streets were tree lined and the houses were interesting to look at. There are lots in nice apartments to rent and most are as trendy as the area. The shopping is good and stocks a lot of local brands. There are lots of artists who set up shop weekends in the Plaza Cortázar. (Well it closed while we were there and protestors (vendors) wanted it reopened).If you like to walk there are lots of areas to explore. At least twice we walked downtown along Avenida Santa Fe.
